child.pub-comments: "It is often suggested that the Kuki-Chin languages are specifically related to Naga languages (Ao, Lhota, Sema and others) (Shafer 1974; Bradley 1996). […] no comparative study has yet been conducted to test the claim of genetic relationship between Kuki-Chin and Naga languages" (Peiros 1998:180).
child.geography: Spoken mostly in mountainous areas of the India-Burma-Bangladesh border

child.pub-comments: "It is possible that Tibetan is specifically related to Cuona Menba (described in Sun et al. 1980 and Lu 1986) and some other languages and dialects which Bradley includes in his East Bodish group. This hypothesis has not been investigated in detail" (Peiros 1998:178).

child.pub-comments: "Formally interpreting the percentages of shared lexicon between the languages one obtains a classification with two main branches: Proper Lolo-Burmese and Naxi. But these two branches are very close to each other and the differences between them can be explained by insufficient knowledge of Naxi, which has no close relatives among the Lolo-Burmese languages. If such an assumption is correct the Lolo-Burmese tree would consist of some independent branches: Burmic, Lolo, Naxi and perhaps Nusu. As I have no proof of this assumption I prefer to use the first variant of the classification (with two main branches), but such a decision is not well grounded" (Peiros 1998:172).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Formally interpreting the percentages of shared lexicon between the languages one obtains a classification with two main branches: Proper Lolo-Burmese and Naxi. But these two branches are very close to each other and the differences between them can be explained by insufficient knowledge of Naxi, which has no close relatives among the Lolo-Burmese languages. If such an assumption is correct the Lolo-Burmese tree would consist of some independent branches: Burmic, Lolo, Naxi and perhaps Nusu. As I have no proof of this assumption I prefer to use the first variant of the classification (with two main branches), but such a decision is not well grounded" (Peiros 1998:172).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "In 1916 Laufer proposed that the Tangut language is closely related to the Lolo-Burmese branch (Laufer 1916) and additional material supporting this hypothesis is given in Nishida (1973:257-273)" (Peiros 1998:177).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Sometimes Jiarung is connected with the Tibetan group (Shafer 1974) but lexicostatistics does not support this classification (Jakhontov 1979a; Peiros & Starostin 1986)" (Peiros 1998:178).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Jakhontov (1979) suggests that the Qiang dialects are closely related to Tangut and form with it a group specifically connected to the Lolo-Burmese languages. Bradley (1996) mentions the possibility of grouping the Qiang languages with Zaba, Muya, Tosu, Pumi, and some other languages of Sichuan and Northern Yunnan (Anon. 1991; Huang 1992)" (Peiros 1998:178).
child.geography: Spoken in some mountainous areas of the Chinese province Sichuan
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Kaike (Hale 1973), which was erroneously considered a Tibetan dialect (Glover 1974:13), forms a separate group without close affiliations to other Tibeto-Burman languages. Bradley includes this language together with Gurung and Thakali in his West Bodish group" (Peiros 1998:178).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.geography: Spoken in the western part of Nepal
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.geography: Spoken in Central and South Burma

Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Shafer (1974) put the language in his Naga-Kuki-Chin group and gave some Mikir etymologies, which need to be tested against more reliable modern data" (Peiros 1998:180).
child.geography: Spoken in some parts of Assam

child.pub-comments: The exact placement of this language within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given. The author notes that it is "sometimes grouped with Tibetan. Modern data (Das Gupta 1968; Zhang 1986), however, do not support such a relationship" (Peiros 1998:178).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "The languages have been strongly influences by Tibetan, and their lexicons include many Tibetan loans. A belief among linguists that these languages should be grouped together with Tibetan has probably been prompted by these loans" (Peiros 1998:183).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that this is not an exhaustive list of languages in this subgroup. "It is possible that Bodo-Garo is specifically related to the Northern Naga group" (Peiros 1998:181).

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that this is not an exhaustive list of languages in this subgroup. The exact placement of this subgroup within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given, but the author notes that "It is often connected to Bodo-Garo and Northern Naga" (Peiros 1998:181).

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that this is not an exhaustive list of languages in this subgroup. The exact placement of this subgroup within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given; however, "It is possible that Bodo-Garo is specifically related to the Northern Naga group" (Peiros 1998:181).

child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that this is not an exhaustive list of languages in this subgroup. The exact placement of this subgroup within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given; however, "All languages of the group are influenced by Tibetan, and ancient Tibetan loans probably can be found in Proto Gurung as well. This fact perhaps explains why the languages are often connected with Tibetan. Bradley includes them in his West Bodish together with Kaike" (Peiros 1998:179).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: The exact placement of this language within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given, but the author notes that "Shafer (1974) includes Manipuri (Meithei) in his Naga-Kuki-Chin group" (Peiros 1998:181).
child.geography: Spoken in the area close to the Naga and Kuki-Chin territories
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: The exact placement of this subgroup within the Sino-Tibetan group is not given; however, "It is often suggested that the Kuki-Chin languages are specifically related to Naga languages (Ao, Lhota, Sema and others) (Shafer 1974; Bradley 1996). […] no comparative study has yet been conducted to test the claim of genetic relationship between Kuki-Chin and Naga languages" (Peiros 1998:180).
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "Berling (1982) has suggested that Kachin should be grouped together with Bodo-Garo, Northern Naga and Luish as a branch of Sino-Tibetan. As there is no convincing evidence that these words represent genetic affiliation rather than local features, more evidence is needed to support this suggestion" (Peiros 1998:182).
child.geography: Spoken in northern parts of Burma and in the Yunnan province of China
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.

child.pub-comments: "[Lepcha] exhibits no specific affiliations with other Sino-Tibetan languages, although Shafer (1974) erroneously connected it with the Kuki-Chin group" (Peiros 1998:182).
child.geography: Spoken in some areas of Nepal and India
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
